newsitem.title: JAPAN: Asian traders say LME copper might try resistance.
newsitem.headline: Asian traders say LME copper might try resistance.

text.p: Copper prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) might try to climb above the next resistance point again soon, despite a sense that the metal is overbought, Asian traders said on Wednesday.
"There's a feeling copper is overbought. But no one looks to be selling, except for producers," said a trader. "It might not be today but copper might try the $2,620 resistance (level) again."
Another trader agreed, saying: "There's nothing to cool down the strong sentiment. LME stocks are falling. There might be a crisis if it falls through 100,000 tonnes."
On Tuesday, the stocks were at 122,225 tonnes.

At 0530 GMT, no quote was available for the benchmark three-month copper. It stood at $2,583/84 at 1800 GMT on Tuesday and at $2,582 at the London kerb close after scoring fresh highs at $2,609 last week.
Three-month aluminium was quoted at $1,587/91, slightly above the kerb close at $1,584.
Traders said aluminium looked firm despite some worries that a fall in LME stocks was caused by a build-up in consignment to stocks rather than to end-users.
"Premiums for spot trades remain high. Selling by producers seems to be mostly over," said a trader. "It might struggle but it will eventually go above $1,600 again."
